categories.name: Syntax & Compilation
categories.description: Code compiles without errors, proper syntax and language conventions, appropriate use of language features relevant to Variables and Data Types, Functions/Methods, Input/Output Operations, Code Organization, Comments and Documentation, Problem Solving Approaches.

categories.name: Logic & Correctness
categories.description: Algorithm correctness, proper implementation of requirements, handles edge cases appropriately, demonstrates understanding of Variables and Data Types, Functions/Methods, Input/Output Operations, Code Organization, Comments and Documentation, Problem Solving Approaches.

categories.name: Output & Functionality
categories.description: Produces expected output format, meets all functional requirements, handles input/output correctly, demonstrates working solution.

categories.name: Style & Documentation
categories.description: Clear variable and function names, proper indentation and formatting, appropriate comments, follows coding best practices.

category_scores.reasoning: The code compiles and runs without syntax errors. However, the student did not include the test program in a separate file as is standard practice, and instead included it in the main method of the Cuboid class.

The `getVolume` method is incorrect; it should return `l * w * h`, but it currently returns `l * h`. The default constructor correctly initializes the object, and the parameterized constructor correctly initializes the object. The `displayInfo` method is mostly correct, but it prints the volume using the incorrect `getVolume` method. The call to the four-argument constructor from the no-argument constructor is missing. The student also did not use `this` to call the four-argument constructor from the no-argument constructor. The test program correctly instantiates two objects and calls `displayInfo` on both.

The output is mostly correct, but the volume is incorrect due to the error in the `getVolume` method. The `displayInfo` method prints all the required information, but the volume is wrong. The dimensions and color are displayed correctly.

Variable and method names are clear and follow Java conventions. Indentation and formatting are consistent. However, there are no comments or documentation explaining the code. The `this` keyword was not used to invoke the four-argument constructor from the no-argument constructor as requested.

feedback.overall_comment: The student has created a `Cuboid` class with basic structure and functionality. The constructors and getter methods are implemented correctly, and the `displayInfo` method generally works as expected. However, there is a significant logical error in the `getVolume` method, and the no-argument constructor does not invoke the parameterized constructor as specified in the requirements. The code also lacks documentation and the test program is embedded within the `Cuboid` class. Addressing these points will significantly improve the submission.
strengths: The `Cuboid` class is well-structured with private attributes and public methods.
Getter methods for all attributes are correctly implemented.
The parameterized constructor and the `getSurfaceArea` method are implemented correctly.
The `displayInfo` method is mostly functional and prints most of the required information.
areas_for_improvement: The `getVolume` method needs to be corrected to `return l * w * h;`.
The no-argument constructor should invoke the four-argument constructor using `this(1, 1, 1, "white");` to follow instructions.
Consider adding comments to explain the purpose of the class, constructors, and methods. This improves code readability and maintainability.
For larger programs, it's good practice to separate the test code into a different file or at least a separate class to maintain better organization.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect Volume Calculation
misconceptions.description: The student calculated the volume of the cuboid incorrectly. The formula for the volume of a cuboid is length * width * height, but the student implemented it as length * height.

evidence.note: Incorrect implementation of the getVolume method.

misconceptions.name: Constructor Chaining
misconceptions.description: The student did not use the `this` keyword to chain constructors as explicitly requested in the prompt. The no-argument constructor should call the parameterized constructor to initialize the object.

evidence.note: The no-argument constructor is not calling the parameterized constructor using 'this'.
